text:
Been lurking here for a while, thought I'd share my 2 months experience with Ozempic.

On the positive side, 20 pounds gone and I feel like a different person and I'm only halfway to my goal. my A1C dropped from 7.7 to 6.0 and my doctor is thrilled - my endocrinologist is really pleased.

But it hasn't been all smooth sailing. the nausea is real and it can be debilitating at times throughout the day. I've thrown up a few times, which is definitely not fun throughout the day. digestive slowdown is real - constipation is annoying which gets worse as the week goes on.

Found that crackers and bland foods makes it more tolerable. I'm told the side effects usually get better after a few weeks.

Anyway, that's my update!

Update time! almost a year on Ozempic and wow,

The good news: the weight is literally melting off - down 25 lbs already and people are actually noticing. the food noise in my head is completely gone.

However, there are definitely some challenges. the fatigue during the first week was intense it seems to come in waves.

My doctor recommended crackers and bland foods which helps. For me, these results are absolutely worth the discomfort. I'm staying committed to seeing this through.

One day at a time, right?

I started my Ozempic journey 2 months ago and honestly,

The good news: I'm finally not thinking about food 24/7. feeling more energetic than I have in years.

But it hasn't been all smooth sailing. I've thrown up a few times, which is definitely not fun especially in the mornings.

Everything I've read says these symptoms are temporary.

Just wanted to share - hang in there everyone!

After 2 months on this medication, I feel like I need to talk about this. My doctor prescribed this for T2D.

I have to say the benefits are real - lost 50 lbs so far and people are starting to notice and people are actually noticing.

But it hasn't been all smooth sailing. nausea hits me hard, particularly in the mornings particularly in the first 2-3 days after injection.

My doctor says these side effects should improve as my body adjusts.

Still figuring this out but staying hopeful.

Been lurking here for a while, thought I'd share my a month experience with Ozempic. I've been reading this sub for a while and finally ready to share.

I have to say the benefits are real - the weight is literally melting off - down 50 lbs already and people are actually noticing. blood sugar control is the best it's been in years and I feel so much better overall.

However, there are definitely some challenges. the nausea is real and it can be debilitating at times especially in the mornings. bathroom trips are more frequent with some diarrhea mostly during the first week of each new dose.

Using anti-nausea medication from my doctor to cope and it's working okay. This is temporary discomfort for long-term health.

Anyone else experiencing similar things? Sorry for the wall of text!

I started my Ozempic journey 8 months ago and honestly,

I have to say the benefits are real - the fatigue I used to feel is mostly gone.

The side effects though... they're real. the nausea is real and it can be debilitating at times particularly in the first 2-3 days after injection.

Using ginger tea and small frequent meals to cope and it's working okay. The trade-off is worth it when I see the progress. I keep reminding myself why I started this.

Would love to hear others' experiences!

After about 3 weeks on this medication, I feel like I need to talk about this. Posting because I think others might relate to my experience.

On the positive side, I have so much more energy throughout the day.

The side effects though... they're real. I do get waves of nausea that can be intense throughout the day. my hair doesn't feel as thick as it used to particularly in the first 2-3 days after injection.

But honestly, I'm managing it with taking it before bed so I sleep through the worst. The benefits far outweigh the side effects in my opinion. I keep reminding myself why I started this.

Hope this helps someone considering it.

Real talk - almost a year on Ozempic has been... Posting because I think others might relate to my experience.

I have to say the benefits are real - I'm down 25 pounds and my clothes are fitting so much better and I'm only halfway to my goal.

One day at a time, right? Sorry for the wall of text!

After almost a year on this medication, I feel like I need to talk about this.

What's working really well: lost 40 lbs so far and people are starting to notice and I'm only halfway to my goal.

Now for the not-so-great part. occasional vomiting episodes that come out of nowhere mostly during the first week of each new dose.

For me, these results are absolutely worth the discomfort.

Hope this helps someone considering it.

So I've been on Ozempic for almost a year now and wanted to share my experience.

The results have been amazing - my A1C dropped from 9.8 to 6.6 and my doctor is thrilled which I never thought would be possible.

However, there are definitely some challenges. I do get waves of nausea that can be intense throughout the day.

This is temporary discomfort for long-term health.

Anyway, that's my update! Sorry for the wall of text!

Real talk - 5 months on Ozempic has been... I've been reading this sub for a while and finally ready to share.

On the positive side, I've lost 40 pounds and honestly I can't believe it which is more than I ever lost on any diet.

But it hasn't been all smooth sailing. diarrhea is manageable but definitely inconvenient mostly during the first week of each new dose. the constipation is uncomfortable and persistent mostly during the first week of each new dose. had some vomiting issues, especially if I eat too much especially in the mornings.

The benefits far outweigh the side effects in my opinion.

Would love to hear others' experiences!

So I've been on Ozempic for 7 months now and wanted to share my experience. I've been reading this sub for a while and finally ready to share.

The good news: the weight is literally melting off - down 50 lbs already - I've gone down two sizes already.

But it hasn't been all smooth sailing. the constipation is uncomfortable and persistent particularly in the first 2-3 days after injection.

Found that eating smaller portions and staying hydrated makes it more tolerable. Everything I've read says these symptoms are temporary.

One day at a time, right?

Been lurking here for a while, thought I'd share my 3 months experience with Ozempic. I'm a 28F/M and started at 235 lbs.

On the positive side, blood sugar control is the best it's been in years which I never thought would be possible. the scale shows 15 pounds down and I'm not even trying that hard and honestly it feels surreal.

Now for the not-so-great part. reflux symptoms are more pronounced now particularly in the first 2-3 days after injection.

Found that anti-nausea medication from my doctor makes it more tolerable. The benefits far outweigh the side effects in my opinion. My health was getting worse so this feels like the right choice.

Anyone else experiencing similar things?

Okay so, 2 months into Ozempic and here's what's happening:

The good news: I can actually feel full and satisfied after normal portions. A1C improvement is incredible - 7.8 down to 6.3 and I feel so much better overall.

Now for the not-so-great part. the constipation is uncomfortable and persistent throughout the day.

But honestly, I'm managing it with ginger tea and small frequent meals. Honestly, it's a small price to pay for these results.

Just wanted to share - hang in there everyone! Thanks for reading this long post!

Just wanted to give an update after 3 months on Ozempic.

The results have been amazing - the constant cravings have disappeared.

The downsides I'm experiencing: I've thrown up a few times, which is definitely not fun which gets worse as the week goes on.

But honestly, I'm managing it with eating smaller portions and staying hydrated. I'm told the side effects usually get better after a few weeks.

Happy to answer any questions!

Just wanted to give an update after 7 months on Ozempic.

The downsides I'm experiencing: occasional vomiting episodes that come out of nowhere which gets worse as the week goes on.

The trade-off is worth it when I see the progress.

Happy to answer any questions! Thanks for reading this long post!

Just wanted to give an update after 4 months on Ozempic. Posting because I think others might relate to my experience.

I have to say the benefits are real - the fatigue I used to feel is mostly gone.

Now for the not-so-great part. the nausea is pretty rough, especially in the first few days after injection particularly in the first 2-3 days after injection. occasional vomiting episodes that come out of nowhere throughout the day.

Compared to the health risks I was facing, this is manageable.

Just wanted to share - hang in there everyone!

So I've been on Ozempic for 4 months now and wanted to share my experience. I was hesitant at first but decided to give it a try.

What's working really well: the constant cravings have disappeared.

The downsides I'm experiencing: digestive slowdown is real - constipation is annoying mostly during the first week of each new dose.

I'm handling it by prescription anti-nausea meds. I know it's tough but the alternative was worse.

Still figuring this out but staying hopeful. This sub has been so helpful for me.

I started my Ozempic journey 6 weeks ago and honestly,

What's working really well: the food noise in my head is completely gone.

But it hasn't been all smooth sailing. I do get waves of nausea that can be intense especially in the mornings. heartburn is a new thing I'm dealing with it seems to come in waves.

I'm handling it by prescription anti-nausea meds. Honestly, it's a small price to pay for these results.

Hope this helps someone considering it.

Quick check-in after 5 months on this medication:

The good news: I've lost 15 pounds and honestly I can't believe it and people are actually noticing. my glucose readings are consistently in normal range now - my endocrinologist is really pleased.

The downsides I'm experiencing: the vomiting is sporadic but when it happens it's rough it seems to come in waves. dealing with persistent headaches, especially early on it seems to come in waves.

Apparently this is normal in the beginning and should improve.

Would love to hear others' experiences!

Update time! almost a year on Ozempic and wow,

What's working really well: blood sugar levels are finally stable - went from 9.8 to 6.2 and I feel so much better overall.

Now for the not-so-great part. exhaustion hits me in waves throughout the week throughout the day. struggling with constipation more than I expected which gets worse as the week goes on. the nausea is pretty rough, especially in the first few days after injection which gets worse as the week goes on.

My doctor recommended crackers and bland foods which helps. Hoping these issues resolve as I continue with the medication.

Still figuring this out but staying hopeful.

But it hasn't been all smooth sailing. reflux symptoms are more pronounced now especially in the mornings.

I'm handling it by prescription anti-nausea meds. My doctor says these side effects should improve as my body adjusts.

Happy to answer any questions!

On the positive side, the weight is literally melting off - down 30 lbs already and honestly it feels surreal. my energy levels are through the roof.

Hope this helps someone considering it. This sub has been so helpful for me.

Anyway, that's my update!

But it hasn't been all smooth sailing. diarrhea is manageable but definitely inconvenient particularly in the first 2-3 days after injection.

The benefits far outweigh the side effects in my opinion. I'm staying committed to seeing this through.

Would love to hear others' experiences!

Just wanted to give an update after 3 months on Ozempic.

I have to say the benefits are real - 25 pounds gone and I feel like a different person which is more than I ever lost on any diet. my energy levels are through the roof.

Anyone else experiencing similar things?

Just wanted to give an update after 9 months on Ozempic. I'm a 52F/M and started at 215 lbs.

The good news: I have so much more energy throughout the day.

The downsides I'm experiencing: the vomiting is sporadic but when it happens it's rough it seems to come in waves. tiredness is a real issue I'm working through it seems to come in waves.

My doctor recommended anti-nausea medication from my doctor which helps. My doctor says these side effects should improve as my body adjusts.

Hope this helps someone considering it.

Been lurking here for a while, thought I'd share my 3 months experience with Ozempic.

The good news: the weight is literally melting off - down 55 lbs already - I've gone down two sizes already. my appetite is so much more manageable now.

But it hasn't been all smooth sailing. getting headaches that I didn't have before especially in the mornings.

Hoping these issues resolve as I continue with the medication.

Would love to hear others' experiences!

I feel more tired than usual, especially after injection day especially in the mornings.

Apparently this is normal in the beginning and should improve.

Anyway, that's my update! This sub has been so helpful for me.

Update time! over a year on Ozempic and wow,

The good news: the scale shows 50 pounds down and I'm not even trying that hard and honestly it feels surreal. blood sugar levels are finally stable - went from 8.4 to 6.3 and I feel so much better overall.

However, there are definitely some challenges. bathroom trips are more frequent with some diarrhea it seems to come in waves.

Hoping these issues resolve as I continue with the medication.

One day at a time, right? Appreciate this community so much.

But honestly, I'm managing it with eating smaller portions and staying hydrated. I'd take these side effects over where I was before any day.

Just wanted to share - hang in there everyone!

I started my Ozempic journey 9 months ago and honestly,

On the positive side, the weight is literally melting off - down 15 lbs already and I'm only halfway to my goal. my glucose readings are consistently in normal range now - no more afternoon crashes.

However, there are definitely some challenges. the vomiting is sporadic but when it happens it's rough especially in the mornings. diarrhea comes and goes - it's unpredictable which gets worse as the week goes on.

One day at a time, right?

I'm told the side effects usually get better after a few weeks.

Still figuring this out but staying hopeful.

The good news: the weight is literally melting off - down 50 lbs already - I've gone down two sizes already.

Now for the not-so-great part. the constipation is uncomfortable and persistent it seems to come in waves. exhaustion hits me in waves throughout the week especially in the mornings. nausea hits me hard, particularly in the mornings throughout the day.

My doctor recommended prescription anti-nausea meds which helps. Everything I've read says these symptoms are temporary.

Just wanted to share - hang in there everyone!

Alright, over a year update on my Ozempic experience. I've been reading this sub for a while and finally ready to share.

What's working really well: blood sugar control is the best it's been in years and I feel so much better overall.

However, there are definitely some challenges. headaches have been more frequent since starting throughout the day. had some vomiting issues, especially if I eat too much it seems to come in waves. constipation has been an ongoing issue I'm dealing with mostly during the first week of each new dose.

I'm handling it by prescription anti-nausea meds. Honestly, it's a small price to pay for these results.

Just wanted to share - hang in there everyone! Appreciate this community so much.

Okay so, 8 months into Ozempic and here's what's happening:

The good news: I have so much more energy throughout the day. my A1C dropped from 7.9 to 6.1 and my doctor is thrilled and I feel so much better overall.

However, there are definitely some challenges. heartburn is a new thing I'm dealing with especially in the mornings.

This is temporary discomfort for long-term health. I keep reminding myself why I started this.

Still figuring this out but staying hopeful.

Update time! 2 months on Ozempic and wow,

The results have been amazing - I have so much more energy throughout the day.

But it hasn't been all smooth sailing. digestive issues including some diarrhea episodes it seems to come in waves. headaches have been more frequent since starting throughout the day.

I know it's tough but the alternative was worse. I'm staying committed to seeing this through.

Would love to hear others' experiences!

Just wanted to give an update after over a year on Ozempic. I'm a 28F/M and started at 255 lbs.

I have to say the benefits are real - my glucose readings are consistently in normal range now and I feel so much better overall.

Now for the not-so-great part. diarrhea comes and goes - it's unpredictable mostly during the first week of each new dose. had some vomiting issues, especially if I eat too much it seems to come in waves. the nausea is pretty rough, especially in the first few days after injection particularly in the first 2-3 days after injection.

But honestly, I'm managing it with ginger tea and small frequent meals. For me, these results are absolutely worth the discomfort. My health was getting worse so this feels like the right choice.

Just wanted to share - hang in there everyone! This sub has been so helpful for me.

After 8 months on this medication, I feel like I need to talk about this. I'm a 32F/M and started at 225 lbs.

What's working really well: blood sugar levels are finally stable - went from 8.7 to 6.6 - my endocrinologist is really pleased.

The downsides I'm experiencing: digestive slowdown is real - constipation is annoying which gets worse as the week goes on.

Hoping these issues resolve as I continue with the medication.

Still figuring this out but staying hopeful.

Challenges I've faced: noticing my hair is thinning a bit which is concerning. This has been difficult to manage.

I'm managing by prescription anti-nausea meds. I'd take these side effects over where I was before any day. This medication has given me hope for better health.

I would recommend this to others dealing with similar health issues.

Started Ozempic a month ago prescribed by my doctor for Type 2 Diabetes. As a 42-year-old with weight issues, this has been life-changing.

Challenges I've faced: dealing with persistent headaches, especially early on. It's affecting my daily life.

The side effects are too much for me to continue long-term.

I've been taking Ozempic for about 3 weeks for Type 2 Diabetes.

The drawbacks: occasional vomiting episodes that come out of nowhere. It's been quite challenging.

Consult carefully with your doctor about potential side effects.

After 6 weeks using Ozempic for Weight Loss, here's my honest review:

The positives: my A1C dropped from 8.0 to 5.9 and my doctor is thrilled. This has reduced my need for other medications the weight is literally melting off - down 32 lbs already. I feel more confident and healthier

Challenges I've faced: the nausea is pretty rough, especially in the first few days after injection. This has been difficult to manage.

Everyone's experience is different, but this is mine.

The negative aspects: tiredness is a real issue I'm working through. Some days are worse than others.

I'm not sure this medication is right for me.

I've been taking Ozempic for almost a year for Weight Loss. As a 55-year-old with type 2 diabetes, this has been life-changing.

The negative aspects: constipation has been an ongoing issue I'm dealing with. It's been quite challenging the fatigue during the first week was intense. Some days are worse than others.
